ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were also recorded pre lab lectures.
We had the option of taking lab in-person or virtually. Virtual labs were occasionally recorded.

I took this course as a remote student.
The data was given to us by the professor for the lab reports for the majority of the time. There were also live Zoom sessions for lab techniques.
live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
Lab over Zoom and pre-recorded lab lecture videos
Recorded pre-lab lecture videos, live virtual meeting

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Literally none. You need a virtual lab for pre-med. Will you learn anything, no.
I learned about General Chemistry experimental methods.

I observed lab skills and techniques concerning a variety of different chemistry topics, but did not absorb as many techniques because of the virtual format and because I was not able to practice the skills myself.

Honestly I feel like I did not learn much. In the lab, you follow a step-by-step instruction manual, and for the lab reports you just fill out the template with the data you collected. A lot of times it felt like i was just blindly following everything and didn't always understand what I was doing and why.

Honestly, I don't know how much utility a virtual lab has from a learning perspective. Since I took the corresponding course in the spring, it was nice to review the concepts and I did get a better understanding of acid-base chemistry and redox reactions than I did in the lecture.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Actually test us on things that we have learned. So many of the quizzes tested us on topics we hadn't yet covered in gen-chem lecture which hurt our grades (as compared to people who had already taken gen chem).

This course was well organized and had clear weekly assignments. It could perhaps have benefited from clearer lab instructions, however; there were lots of day-of-lab changes to the lab manuals which were slightly confusing. I'm sure that could be fixed for next year. Everything was a strength.
Professor Cooper did a fantastic job of keeping the students occupied and engaged with the material. Obviously, this course would be better in-person, but we did the best with what we could.

For future online sessions, please give all the data in one file and/or folder. Getting data in separate announcements, excel sheets, Microsoft word files, AND live sessions was an actual pain and incredibly messy. Not to mention, made it harder for everyone.  Also it would be nice to see where we went wrong on the quizzes, so making those available would be great.

Strengths were that Prof. Cooper handled the virtual lab session very well (his demonstrations through the Zoom call were very useful) and Hannah was very helpful in providing feedback on our work. Weaknesses include that we had a lot of additional assignments (in addition to lab reports), which felt overwhelming at times (especially since everything was virtual).

I think once weakness of the course was how sometimes students did not receive clear feedback on what they were doing wrong and how they could improve. I would recommend opening up the quizzes to view wrong answers and adding explanations for the correct one. One strength was the live virtual lab where we could see the lab play out in real time.

The strength was that the professors put in their best effort to give the virtual students the best experience possible given that we were unable to go into labI appreciate the commitment to structuring the virtual lab in such a way that would allow us to virtually learn lab skills. However, the weakness is that often there was a large amount of unnecessary and tedious work added into the virtual experiencefor example, we were asked to copy down digital data files in our lab notebooks that would not be necessary in the in-person lab setting and ultimately didn't add anything to our learning experience.

A big weakness: the lab manual usually just feel like a big step-by-step instruction manual. Sometimes you don't really know what you're doing, but you just follow what the manual says. It makes it hard to actually understand the procedures and why they work.

I don't really think that there is any way to run a virtual lab like this in an effective way. The course wasn't great, but I don't see how it could have been, and the professor did a good job given the situation.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online quizzes and online submission of lab notebook pages were very successful, and I think those could be kept even when virtual learning has ended. It really made the assignments easy to turn in. The online pre-lab lectures were not bad, but also not excellent -- I don't think the change in format affected their quality for better or for worse.
I think this class did the best it could during the pandemic. It is hard to do a lab virtually, but they made it work!

After some trial and error, we ultimately settled on a virtual format that I feel was very successful. Dr. Cooper had us walk him through the procedures of the lab, so we were all able to ask questions and learn from mistakes. In a way, I feel like I learned more from the virtual experience because we were being taught the entire time. Of course, watching is different from actually doing, but I don't think we were really taught proper technique in in-person lab anyway, so I'm kind of glad I missed out on the more stressful parts of lab like fending for yourself, freaking out about how little time is left, and watching your friend get scolded for breaking a beaker.
The Thursday sections were a nice way to still have access to the lab.
The Zoom sessions were helpful if you were confused about lab techniques.

I think the combination of the live virtual lab and prerecorded lectures worked well for this semester during the pandemic. I do not think the Labster simulations were as helpful as professors thought.

I wish there would be a little more discussion of the concepts in the lab reports after they had been done, but I get the sense that student engagement was pretty low for this course so it may not have been fruitful. The labster simulations felt like an enormous waste of time, and although I understand what the rationale for assigning them was, it still just felt like busy work to pad out the course time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely take this course if you need to take chemistry lab. Dr. Cooper is a  great teacher and this course has been improved significantly from past years. You will finish with a much better understanding of chemistry lab techniques, particularly if you take this course in-person.
Not if it's not a pre-req.
Most people who take this course have to take it, but it is a decent lab class to take. I think I would recommend it, but be wary that this class comes with lots of work (as most chem labs do).
Much better than gen Chen lab with dr. G
Most students who are going to be taking this course are taking it because it was a requirement for their major of for the pre-med track, so for this reason I would recommend it.
I wouldn't recommend this course unless you absolutely need to take it. It is very poorly designed and I felt like I didn't learn much at all.
